title: Charles-Tim
author: Charles-Tim
created_time: May 17, 2023, 08:55:47 PMLast edit: May 20, 2023, 11:35:11 PM by Charles-Tim
content: Online/hot wallets should only be for little amount of bitcoin. For high amount of bitcoin, use offline wallet.I have noticed using Trustwallet is common among we Nigerians on this forum. Some of us are also probably using wallets that experienced bitcoin users can not advice anyone to use. I think you need to know what an excellent bitcoin wallet is. Note that there are many excellent bitcoin wallets that are open source. Features that excellent bitcoin wallet should haveopen sourcemultiple address generationfee customizationReplace-by-fee (RBF) supportChild-pay-for-patent (CPFP) supportCoin controlThe most important features are: (1) a wallet should be open source so that the public can be able to check the source code, this can help the public to know that there is no spyware or other vulnerabilities included in the code of the wallet,  (2) multiple address generation for privacy reasons, (3) RBF which would be helpful to increase transaction fee, to have higher chance for your coin that you transfer to get confirmed earlier and (4) fee customization.Among the wallets that I am using, Desktop Electrum and Bluewallet are the once that have all these features. Mobile Electrum is not bad either. For wallets that support opt-in RBF, read this: Bitcoin open source wallets that support replace-by-fee (RBF)There are many wallets, but just the only two wallets that I am using are those mentioned. If you have used a wallet that has all those features, like being open source, generating many addresses, having fee customization and RBF, you can mention it too. Trustwallet is not an open source wallet, not supporting RBF and not generating multiple addresses. It has only one bitcoin address. Not supporting CPFP and not supporting coin control. Even just address freeze, it is not supporting it.

comments.author: Davidvictorson
comments.body: Thank you for this expository and informative piece, Charles. I am currently using Desktop Electrum. I have yet to try Bluewallet, though I have heard of it in the past. I guess this is the sign I need to check it out. For now, I would not experiment with the mobile Electrum wallet; let's just say I am not comfortable with it on a mobile device.Two of the most important features that you have mentioned, which I do like about the Electrum Bitcoin wallet (I know that it is not limited to it but to other Bitcoin wallets as well), are the multiple address generation for privacy's sake and the RBF. I know how the former feature helped "fast-track my transactions" during the network congestion period.Speaking about Trustwallet, I never liked it. Although, one time I was forced to use it for non-Bitcoin related transactions, but since then, I haven't opened the app unless the Play Store notifies me that I need to update it.
